messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] akasaka tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Jim Gilbert s page on Akasaka tsuba, which I happened to be rereading a couple of nights ago, covers this. Short answer: Yes, it can be one of the
messages.messageBody:
Jim Gilbert's page on Akasaka tsuba, which I happened to be rereading a
couple of nights ago, covers this.

Short answer: Yes, it can be one of the characteristics.

Long answer: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/akasaka.htm

Craig

----- Original Message -----
From: <MuramasaIII@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, June 04, 2003 10:45 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] akasaka tsuba question


> Hi ye all,
> on one of e-bay's auction, the seller mentioned this " the tsuba is made
of
> three plate construction which is one of the characteristics of Akasaka ".
>
> Is this true ?
>
>
> Milt
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] akasaka tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, True, but like an M&M. Harder darker steel outside, softer browner stuff inside. Not quite as problematic(?) as shakudo tsuba 3 piece construction, where
messages.messageBody:
Milt,

True, but like an M&M. Harder darker steel outside,
softer browner stuff inside.

Not quite as problematic(?) as shakudo tsuba 3 piece
construction, where you see more seperation. -although
I do have an interesting tsuba of similar construction
that shows some seperation. (Iron) 3 piece
construction is probably the next New York Club
lecture topic around June 22nd or so.

Curran

messages.subject: akasaka tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi ye all, on one of e-bay s auction, the seller mentioned this  the tsuba is made of three plate construction which is one of the characteristics of Akasaka
messages.messageBody:
Hi ye all,
on one of e-bay's auction, the seller mentioned this " the tsuba is made of
three plate construction which is one of the characteristics of Akasaka ".

Is this true ?


Milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
